titlestmt.subtitle: A Guide to her Papers at the Indiana University Archives
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Tyler Davis

note.p: © 2018 Trustees of Indiana University. All rights reserved.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-02-04 04:55:40 -0500.

did.abstract: Esther Thelen (1941-2004) was a professor of psychology at Indiana University Bloomington and a well-known researcher in the field of developmental psychology. She is known for applying the dynamic systems theory to the study of infant motor development; this has since become the dominant theoretical viewpoint in the field. Much of Thelen's research was done at Indiana University Bloomington's Infant Motor Development Laboratory, which she established and directed. This collection contains personal files and correspondence; documents related to public speaking appearances, publications, and roles in professional organizations and committees; educational materials from psychology courses taught by Thelen; and materials related to Thelen's research, including handwritten notes, drafts of studies, and videotapes of research subjects.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Select files closed to researchers; these are indicated in the folder list. Advance notice required for access to collection.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Esther Stillman Thelen was born in Brooklyn, New York on May 20, 1941 to Alden and Sarah Stillman. She attended Antioch College in Ohio, and was a 1964 graduate of the University of Wisconsin with a degree in zoology. She then received a master's degree in zoology and a doctorate in biology, both from the University of Missouri. She began her career as an assistant professor of psychology at the University of Missouri in 1977 before moving to Indiana University in 1985.

During her time at Indiana University, Thelen was a professor of psychology and the founder/director of the Infant Motor Development Laboratory. She and her colleagues studied infant movement, perception, and cognition, and how perceptual motor skills in infancy can predict development and adaption later in life. In the late 1990s, Thelen worked with longtime colleague Linda Smith as well as Gregor Schöner to begin a series of experiments studying the "A-not-B" reaching error in infants.

Thelen is well-known for applying the dynamic systems theory – popularized under the name "chaos theory" – to the study of child development. Through watching and recording babies' behavior, Thelen's 19 years of research demonstrated that infant movement develops through a complex interplay of factors, including changing bodies, growing brains and nervous systems, and interactions with the external environment during a dynamic period of brain development. She disproved the original theory that the stepping reflex in babies appeared only at birth and then disappeared; her research proved that the reflex was still present after birth. Her work also had a major impact on the field of pediatric physical therapy, prompting therapists to design individual exercises tailored to a child's body, rather than using standard exercises for all children within a certain age bracket.

Thelen was president of the Society for Research in Child Development (SRCD) from 2003 to 2004 and served as president of the International Society for Infant Studies (ISIS) from 1996 to 1998. She was a fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science and the American Psychological Association. She received numerous grants from the National Science Foundation, as well as continuous funding from the National Institute of Mental Health.

She was widely published in the fields of psychology, child development, and motor neuroscience. Her research output included three books and over 120 scientific articles and chapters. Her theories have been incorporated into the work of scholars in neuroscience, cognitive science, computer science, robotics, and kinesiology. Thelen was a frequent lecturer all over the world, giving talks and presentations at many different schools, conferences, and workshops. Her work was often featured in national media sources.

In 1962, Esther married David Thelen, a historian who also went on to work at Indiana University as a professor of American history. They had two children together. Thelen passed away from cancer on December 29, 2004.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized into ten series: Conferences, Workshops, and Presentations; Correspondence; Courses and Instruction Materials; Grants and Funding Materials; International Society for Infant Studies (ISIS); National Research Council; Personal Files; Publications; Research; and Society for Research in Child Development (SRCD).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Esther Thelen papers span the years 1977-2005 and mainly document Thelen's time as a researcher and professor of psychology at Indiana University Bloomington (1985-2004). The collection documents Thelen's professional activities, including research and instruction, publication, public speaking events, and leadership roles in organizations including the International Society for Infant Studies (ISIS), the National Research Council, and the Society for Research in Child Development (SRCD). Additionally, the collection contains correspondence files that document Thelen's interactions with her friends, peers, and students; personal files including a document of Thelen's family history and notebooks filled with handwritten notes; as well as documents related to a gender-based salary inequity grievance co-filed by Thelen (and subsequently resolved) at Indiana University Bloomington. Types of materials present in the collection include correspondence, articles, research and instruction materials, photographs, and video data.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: 27 photos, 2 contact sheets, and a number of negatives were removed and are housed with the Archives Photograph Collection. These include professional headshots of Thelen; photos of Thelen and her colleagues interacting with their infant research subjects; photos of the subjects themselves for documentation purposes; as well as a photo of the Indiana University Department of Psychology's "Mobile Research Laboratory" bus, which enabled Thelen and her colleagues to travel to the homes of their research subjects to perform their studies. For more information, please contact the University Archives staff.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Additional publications and research materials may be accessed in IUScholarworks.
Related photographs may be available in the University Archives Photographs Database.

userestrict.head: Usage Restrictions
userestrict.p: For information regarding the copyright status of this collection, please contact the Indiana University Archives staff.

The Indiana University Archives respects the intellectual property rights of others and does not claim any copyrights for non-university records, materials in the public domain, or materials for which we do not hold a Deed of Gift. Responsibility for the determination of the copyright status of these materials rests with those persons wishing to reuse the materials. Researchers are responsible for securing permission from copyright owners and any other rights holders for any reuse of these materials that extends beyond fair use or other statutory limitations.

Digital reproductions of archival materials from the Indiana University Archives are made available for noncommercial educational and research purposes only. If you are the copyright holder for any of the digitized materials and have questions about its inclusion on our site, please contact the Indiana University Archives staff.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item], Esther Thelen papers, C687, Indiana University Archives, Bloomington.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: The materials in this collection were transferred from David Thelen to the University Archives in three accessions from April 2007 to March 2008.

appraisal.head: Appraisal
appraisal.p: Printed copies of articles and publications, both those written by Thelen and those written by other authors, were removed and disposed of unless they contained extensive handwritten notes or personal inscriptions to Thelen from the author(s). The collection includes a complete master list of publications by Thelen.
Recommendation files were weeded, and only files containing a large amount of correspondence, or those containing extensive documents related to Thelen's professional peers, were retained.
Files that Esther Thelen collected from university committees on which she served but which she did not chair were discarded.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series contains materials from various events attended by Thelen from 1989-2003. Thelen was a speaker or presenter at most of these functions, so many files in this series contain her personal notes and lecture materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of letters, postcards, and email printouts written or received by Thelen between 1985-2004 and includes personal and professional correspondence as well as letters of recommendation written on behalf of students and peers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged into two subseries: General and Recommendations. Each subseries is arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains letters, postcards, and printouts of emails exchanged between Thelen and her friends, colleagues, and professional peers from 1985-2004.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains letters of recommendation written by Thelen on behalf of her students and peers, as well as letters retained and filed by Thelen under the name of the correspondents.

accessrestrict.head: Restriction Note:
accessrestrict.p: The records in this series are restricted because they contain sensitive personal information including employment applications and social security numbers. With advance notice, the Archives may be able to redact sensitive information from files and make them available for access.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series includes 35mm transparencies of overhead slides, course evaluations completed by students in Thelen's classes, as well as syllabi, assignment descriptions, and general materials related to psychology courses taught by Thelen at Indiana University Bloomington.

accessrestrict.head: Restriction Note:
accessrestrict.p: Files containing student grades and other sensitive information are restricted. With advance notice, the Archives may be able to redact sensitive information from files and make them available for access.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Research: Video data subseries contains U-Matic videotapes recorded by Thelen and her associates from 1981-1985. The tapes document infant subjects during research testing sessions studying infant movement and cognition. All tapes were recorded while Thelen was working at the University of Missouri.

accessrestrict.head: Restriction Note:
accessrestrict.p: The videotapes in Boxes 10, 11, and 12 are restricted because they contain segments with personally identifiable information (PII), including full name and/or birth date, about the infant research subjects who are depicted in the tapes.

scopecontent.p: This series contains annual reports, financial reports, meeting notes, correspondence, and other administrative records related to the Society for Research in Child Development; Thelen was serving as president of the SRCD at the time of her passing in 2004.
